It is widely accepted that pore size distribution and spatial pore connectivity directly impact on the macroscopic porous medium transport properties. Therefore it is indispensable to characterize nano-micro porous media like shale with multi-scale pore structure to accurately assess fluid transport properties. In this study, we propose a multi-scale pore network model to estimate the fluid transport properties. A 3D binary inorganic porous structure model is constructed from a section of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image which only images large scale inorganic pores and its corresponding inorganic pore network is extracted by the maximal ball fitting method. The nano-porous organic matter is treated as the virtual throat which is embedded in series or parallel connection with the inorganic throat on the original inorganic pore network. Three parameters namely the ratio of total amount of the virtual throat to the total amount of the inorganic throat, the proportion of virtual throat in parallel connection with the inorganic throat and average organic pore radius inside the organic matter are applied to analyze the impact of multi-scale pore structure characteristic on fluid transport properties. The constructed multi-scale pore network model accounts for the organic matter distribution, organic matter total volume, organic pore size, inorganic pore structure and connectivity characteristic between organic and inorganic system all together. Nano-micro scale fluid transport mechanisms are considered in modelling fluid mass transfer. Key analysis results indicate that the fluid mass transfer in nano-micro porous media is influenced by the nano-porous organic matter distribution pattern and it’s local volume. The series connection of nano-porous organic matter and the increase of virtual throat amounts significantly decrease the fluid transport ability. Furthermore, the established multi-scale pore network model is used to interpretate laboratory pressure pulse decay response curve.

Fluid mass transfer and transport property in strong heterogeneous nano-micro porous media have drawnmore andmore attention due to the recent advances of shale gas energy development [1– 3]. The complexities of shale are demonstrated both in the different pore typeswith notably different pore size and complex pore spatial configurations [4–6]. The pores of organic and inorganic type bear significant differences in pore sizes and surface property that generates complex fluid transport behaviors [7,8]. Organic pore sizes are generally usually less than 10 7m in diameter [9,10], while inorganic pore sizes are much larger than organic ones [11–14]. Wu et al. [15] showed that the inorganic pore size ranges from 5 10 8m to 2 10 5m while organic pore size ranges from
port deviates from pure viscous flow as a result of nano-micro pore size and is characterized by Knudsen number [16–19] Furthermore, gas adsorption/desorption takes place on pore wall [20]. The adsorbed gas on the pore surface reduces the effective radius for the bulk gas transport [21,22] and transports along the pore surface in the forms of surface diffusion [23]. Hydraulic fracturing is commonly applied to enhance gas recovery and investigating water transport behavior in nano-micro porousmedia has practical implications in better understanding water injection and flowback process [24–26]. Non-slip flow boundary condition for single phase water transport is not valid in nanopores [27–31] and the water transport flow rates through carbon nanotubes (CNTs) membranes with diameters less than 10 nm are two to five orders of magnitude greater than those calculated by the no-slip Hagen–Poiseuille equation [32,33]. The water flow rate through 44-nm carbon nanopipes is an order of magnitude larger than that calculated by the no-slip Hagen–Poiseuille equation [34]. The slip length of brine in
nanopores is measured using an atomic force microscope (AFM) by Javadpour et al. [35]. In addition, the confined water viscosity in nanopores changes significantly [36–38]. Vinogradova et al. [39] deemed that the slippage effect is caused by the viscosity reduction of the thin layer near the pore wall. Wu et al. [40] established a confined water transport model using the modified Hagen–Poiseuille equation in consideration of the influence of the wettability, viscosity change and nanopore dimension.
The 2D pore characteristics across a wide range of spatial resolutions from meso-scale to nano-scale can be captured by the traditional optical and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging techniques [10], but the pore connectivity of pore networks and pore shape in 3D pore space cannot be detected. Pore size distributionmeasurementsmethod likemercury intrusion porosimetry and nitrogen adsorption can only provide connected porosity, and the connected pore throats diameters [41,42]. The technique for 3D nm-scale pore characterization, Focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy (FIB/SEM) can accurately provide key properties of nano-micro porous media, such as the TOC, mineralogy, porosity and other physical properties [43,44]. However, FIB/SEM can only address a very small volume andmay result in incomplete information by destroying existent pore structures. Furthermore, with the increase of image resolution, the field of view becomes smaller. Given the heterogeneities of shale, it is unreliable to quantify nanopores connectivity with micropores in a representative elementary volume. Therefore, it is essential to developmulti-scale approach to assess fluid transport property and evaluate its influence factors [45–48] Modelling fluid mass transfer in confined pore space of nano-micro porous media has benefited from the advancement in high-resolution imaging techniques [49–53]. The pore network model consequently develops based on the simplified representation of a complex pore space as a realistic pore network composed of connected pore nodes and throats [54–57]. Numerical simulation can be conducted based on the pore network model to predict the critical transport properties. Ma et al. [56,57] developed non-ideal gas pore network transport model and Song et al. [58,59] proposed a pore network model in nanoscale organic porous media which captures real gas transport behaviors and water slip. Afsharpoor et al. [60] established liquid slip transport model in shale noncircular nanopores network. A short overview of existing work on multiscale pore network models is presented here. Bauer et al. [61] improved image-based 3Dpore throat network by including continuum microporous boxes which is in parallel connection with the
macroscale pore throat to model carbonate rock. Mehmani, et al. [62] proposed conceptual pore network models which integrates pores from nanoscale to microscale. Prodanovic et al. constructed two-scale unstructured pore network models to investigate the micro-porosity effects on transport properties [63,64]. Jiang et al. [65] and Pak et al. [66] integratedmultiple networks of various sizes into a single network incorporating all scales and suggested transport properties in carbonate rock are dependent on multiple scales information. Bultreys et al. [67] developed a novel dual pore network model based on the micro-computed-tomography and the micro-porosity is modelled in an upscaled fashion by micro-links referred as symbolic network elements, while the macro-porosity is treated as a traditional pore network model. To the best knowledge of the authors, most of the current multi-scale pore network modelling studies focus on conventional rocks or conceptual models. The comprehensive nanoconfinement effects of both gas and water phases, gas adsorption, pore types (organic pore, inorganic pore), real gas property have not been considered in an existing multi-scale pore-network model to model fluid mass transfer behavior in a nano-micro scale shale rocks at typical reservoir conditions. The purpose of this study is to develop a multi-scale pore network model to accurately estimate fluid transport ability in nano-micro porous media. The nanoconfinement effects and pore surface physicochemical property influence on fluid transport are considered compared with the previous multi-scale pore-network models. Multiple fluid transport mechanisms related with pore type, gas adsorption, real gas equation of state are modelled. More specifically, water transport considers the boundary slip length. Bulk gas transport in inorganic pores considers slip effectwhile bulk gas transport and surface diffusion for adsorbed gas are both considered in organic matter. In Section 2, the multi-scale pore network model is constructed. The total volume of nano-porous organicmatter determined by the total organic carbon (TOC) in volume is equally divided and is treated as the virtual throat which is embedded in series or parallel connection with the inorganic throat on the original inorganic pore network. In Section 3, fluid transportmodels are established. Detailed analysis of fluid transport properties is given in Section 4. This is followed by a section of conclusions.

As the current 3D reconstruction method based on the 2D SEM image can only identify the pore phase and matrix phase and the different pore types cannot be recognized during 3D reconstruction process, we doesn’t differentiate interparticle inorganic pores with intraparticle inorganic pores and only consider the difference between organic system and inorganic system. Organic matter primarily has two geometries: lamellar masses and discrete spheroidal particles. Lamellar organic matter is commonly parallel to sub-parallel to inorganic material and spherical organic matter are discrete with no preferred orientation [70]. In this study, we deem that all the organic pore volume can effectively contribute to the fluid transport. Three different types of throats in the multi scale pore network are established accordingly shown in Fig. 4. 4. Results and analysis

sections.heading: 4.1. Impacts of multi-scale pore structure property on fluid transport properties
sections.text:
Figs. 6 and 7 show gas and water permeability variation with pore pressure at different TOC values. Gas and water permeabilities both slightly increase with the increase of nano-porous organic matter volume. The increase of fluid permeability with the increase of nano-porous organic matter volume matches well with the previous experimental results [99]. Gas permeability increases with the decreasing pore pressure because of the enhanced surface diffusion in organic matter and gas rarefaction effect, namely f(Kn) in relatively low pore pressure as the similar trend is shown in the experimental data [100]. The viscosity of water is more influenced by temperature than pore pressure and therefore water permeability stays almost constant across the pore pressure range from 5 MPa to 50 MPa. Gas and water permeabilities at two extreme cases of pore connectivity conditions (b = 0, b = 1) are shown in Fig. 8. The influence of parallel connection organic matter on permeability is relatively small. Gas permeability is slightly larger than that obtained from simulation of gas flow in inorganic pore network with no organic matter connected on it. Water permeability stays almost the same in these two different conditions. However, when the nano-porous organic matter is entirely in series connection with inorganic throat, the gas and water permeability
can decrease at least 75%. This can be attributed to the fact that the serial connected nano-porous organic matter forms a barrier along the fluid transport pathways and significantly decreases transport ability. The influence of virtual throat amounts on gas and water permeability is shown in Fig. 9. With the increase of virtual throat amounts, the nano-porous organic matter becomes more dispersed in Fig. 10 and the increase of serial connected nano-porous organic matter amounts significantly decreases the gas and water permeability by at least a proportion of 75%.
4.2. Implementation of multi-scale pore network model for pulsedecay permeability analysis
The constructed multi-scale pore network transport model is applied to interpret pulse decay experimental data by predicting permeability to match pressure response curve. The pressure pulse decay process records the decay of upstream pressure data and the increase of downstream pressure data [101–104] and has been widely applied to estimate nano-micro porous media permeability [105,106]. We deem that both inorganic/organic pore amounts are approximately linear proportional to the total inorganic/organic pore volume in the core sample. Fig. 11 shows calculated pressure drop versus time based on the multi-scale pore network transport model compared with experimental data. The pressure pulse decay curve is influenced by the small scale organic matter distribution pattern. The predicted pressure drop decreases more deeply because of the increase of permeability caused by the increase of b. When b equals to 0.7, the predicted pressure drop matches with the experimental data and the predicted permeability value is 4.45 10 6 lm2. The results indicate that the laboratory measured pressure pulsed decay data can be interpreted by adjusting the connectivity characteristic between organic and inorganic system on the multi scale pore network.
5. Conclusions
A multi-scale pore network model was proposed in this work to describe the complex nano-micro porous media and analyze the
fluid transport properties. The constructed multi-scale pore network model considers the organic matter distribution, organic matter total volume, organic pore size, inorganic pore structure and the connectivity characteristic between organic and inorganic system all together. The nano-porous organic matter is treated as the virtual throat which is embedded in series or parallel connection with the inorganic throat on the original inorganic pore network. Permeability was computed at different TOC volumes and pore connectivity conditions. Our study results show that the series connection of nano-porous organic matter and dispersed distribution of organic matter significantly decrease the fluid transport ability. We further apply the established multi-scale pore network model to interpret laboratory measured pressure pulse decay data. The results show that the simulated results can match well with the experimental data by adjusting the connectivity characteristic between organic and inorganic system. There are two limitations of current work. First, we treated the local organic pore volumes equally distributed over each virtual throat. The local organic pore volumes may be non-uniformly distributed for realistic shale nano-porous media. Another limitation is the uncertainty involved during matching with pressure pulse-decay data process. Regarding the first part, we will work on establishing shale dual pore type network extraction model considering both the non-uniform distribution of organic pores and inorganic pore network directly based on high resolution FIB-SEM image. Regarding the second part, more constraint conditions related with the pore structure properties will be put in the interpretation model to reduce the uncertainty. In addition, the multiphase flow process based on the established multi-scale pore network model under mixedwet conditions will be studied in future work.
